item.title: Pomological Plots
item.description: In the real world, when I give talks and use slides I am typically constrained in my aesthetic. Often I‚Äôm speaking at a work-related thing and we have a corporate template and color scheme. They serve us well and I‚Äôve found restraint helps focus on the message. Usually I‚Äôm setting out to inform, so direct, repeatable and easy to follow are key. But I also like to explore new ideas and different themes on the side.

item.title: Forecasting Game
item.description: LET‚ÄôS PICK BACK UP where we left off and think about communicating forecast results. To help guide our thinking, let‚Äôs set up a little game. Basic setup Like last time we‚Äôre going to focus on a situation where a forecaster observes some information about the world and makes an announcement about a future binary outcome. A decision maker observes the forecaster‚Äôs announcement and takes a binary action. Then the outcome is realized and the forecaster receives a payoff.

item.title: Rock that dadbod plot!
item.description: Spring is nearly upon us, or at least we can hope. Let‚Äôs examine how housing activity typically rounds into shape as the weather warms up. We‚Äôll make some fun plots with R. item.title: Mortgage Rate Kandinsky
item.description: THINGS ARE ABOUT TO GET A BIT MORE ABSTRACT IN THIS SPACE. Today we make some Kandinsky-style images with R. This summer I was fortunate to spend some time at the Pompidou Centre in Paris. The Pompidou Centre houses the largest collection of modern art in Europe. I really enjoyed their collection of abstract and minimalist paintings. Well, turns out we can make our own abstract-style art using a Kandinsky R package from Giora Simchoni.

item.description: I WANT TO SHARE WITH YOU a little bit of code to make this whimsical data visualization: Make a simple map First we can construct a map of the lower 48 U.S. states and add a marker for each city.
